value.title: It's Called Artificial Intelligence—but What Is Intelligence?
value.excerpt: Gurgling infants might seem like no match for artificial intelligence. They are terrible at labeling images, hopeless at mining text, and awful at videogames. Then again, babies can do things beyond the reach of any AI.

value.title: Self-driving shuttle company adds seatbelts in order to resume US operations
value.excerpt: French self-driving vehicle company EasyMile will add seatbelts to its shuttles in order to be able to once again carry passengers in the US. EasyMile’s shuttles were suspended by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) in late February after an incident where a passenger fell out of her seat during a sudden stop in Columbus,

images.title: Self-driving shuttle company adds seatbelts in order to resume US operations

value.title: No matter how sophisticated, artificial intelligence systems still need human oversight
value.excerpt: AI and machine learning systems are only as good as the data we feed them. Witness the fallout from the COVID-19 crisis, which threw many AI algorithms out of whack: 'If machines are to be trusted, we need to watch over them.

images.title: No matter how sophisticated, artificial intelligence systems still need human oversight

value.title: UPDATE 1-GM CEO calls self-driving unit layoffs 'prudent,' still sees 'huge opportunity'

value.title: EasyMile Self-Driving Shuttles Add Seatbelts To Get Back In Operation
value.excerpt: EasyMile shut operations due to a sudden-stop incident. It's coming back, adding seatbelts. But is the very idea of the "transit stop" where you drop off and pick up passengers the flaw? Can 21st century transit have minimal stops and thus be safer?

images.title: EasyMile Self-Driving Shuttles Add Seatbelts To Get Back In Operation

value.title: Cruise, GM’s self-driving unit, lays off 8 percent of staff
value.excerpt: Cruise, the self-driving car startup that is a majority-owned subsidiary of General Motors, is laying off 150 employees, or about 8 percent of its workforce, to cut costs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic.
